news.title: National News at a Glance
news.text:
NOAA Said to Be Planning to Shrink Staff by 20%

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the nation's premier agency for weather and climate science, has been told by the Trump administration to prepare to lose another 1,000 workers, raising concerns that NOAA's lifesaving forecasts might be hindered as hurricane season approaches. The new dismissals would come in addition to the roughly 1,300 NOAA staff members who have already resigned or been laid off in recent weeks. Together, the reductions would represent nearly 20% of NOAA's approximately 13,000-member workforce. Some activities, including the launching of weather balloons, have already been suspended because of staffing shortages.

Climate Nonprofit Sues EPA Over Billions in Frozen Funds

A multibillion-dollar dispute between the Environmental Protection Agency and several nonprofit organizations escalated Saturday when one group sued the EPA and Citibank, seeking access to grant money that has been frozen under President Donald Trump. Climate United contends that the EPA and Citibank have illegally withheld an award of nearly $7 billion announced last April. Citibank has housed the funds as part of a program to finance projects that address climate change. Eight nonprofits collectively received $20 billion from the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund during the Biden administration. Now some of the nonprofits say that their bank accounts are frozen and that they are struggling to pay staff members.

House Republicans Unveil Spending Bill to Avert Shutdown at Week's End

House Republicans on Saturday unveiled a measure to fund the government through Sept. 30, boosting spending on the military and daring Democrats to oppose it and risk being blamed for a government shutdown that would begin after midnight Friday. The legislation would slightly decrease spending overall from last year's funding levels, but would increase spending for the military by $6 billion. It was unclear whether the legislation could pass the Republican-controlled Congress. Speaker Mike Johnson will need to navigate the bill through his extremely narrow House majority as early as Tuesday and has just a vote or two to spare if Democrats are unanimously opposed.

14-Year-Old Boy Arrested in Connection With Fatal Newark Police Shooting

A 14-year-old boy has been arrested in connection with a shooting Friday night that killed one Newark, New Jersey, police officer and injured another, Essex County officials said Saturday. The boy, who was also injured, was charged with murder, attempted murder and possessing illegal weapons following the shooting, Theodore N. Stephens II, the Essex County prosecutor, said Saturday. The boy's name has not been released. The officer who was killed was identified Saturday as Joseph Azcona, 26, a detective who had served with the Newark Police Department for five years.

Former Ride-Share Driver Sentenced for Preying on Women

A Denver judge on Friday sentenced a former ride-share driver to 290 years to life after prosecutors said he abducted a dozen women over four years by falsely posing as the driver they requested. The man, John Pastor-Mendoza, was convicted in late October on 30 charges related to the kidnapping, attempted sexual assault and sexual assault of the women between 2018 and 2022. Pastor-Mendoza, 43, who lived in Denver, falsely claimed to be the driver for women who used a ride-sharing app, picking them up outside downtown bars and clubs.

For Black Women, Adrienne Adams Is More Than Just Another Mayoral Candidate

As Adrienne Adams officially kicked off her mayoral campaign Saturday, she urged potential voters at a rally in Jamaica, Queens, to view her as an alternative to New York City's two most recognizable candidates, Mayor Eric Adams and former Gov. Andrew Cuomo. But many of her supporters see her candidacy as something else: an opportunity for Democrats to elect a qualified Black woman as mayor. If elected, she would be the first woman of color to lead the country's largest city. Adrienne Adams, the City Council speaker and a Queens native, faces a tough path amid a crowded field and her own fundraising lag.

This article originally appeared in The New York Times.
news.summary: NOAA Said to Be Planning to Shrink Staff by 20%
news.author: North Adams Pride

news.title: An Elite Russian Drone Group Is Hunting Ukrainian Vehicles In Kursk. It’ll Take More Than A Few MiG-29 Raids To Stop The Russians.
news.text:
Ukrainian MiG-29s.
Ukrainian air force photo

Deploying one of its most effective drone units and hundreds of North Korean troops along with the usual marines and paratroopers, a powerful Russian force squeezed the Ukrainian-held salient in western Russia’s Kursk Oblast last week.

The Russian advance, which began just as the administration of U.S. President Donald Trump was cutting off Ukraine from U.S.-gathered intelligence and shipments of American-made munitions, reversed Ukrainian gains from last month and threatened to cut off the main road leading into the Ukrainian military’s main base in Kursk: the town of Sudzha.

The Ukrainian general staff in Kyiv told Ukrainian Pravda the situation in Kursk, which has been under partial Ukrainian control since August, “remains challenging but under control,” to quote the news site.

But it’s unclear what measures the Ukrainians have taken to defeat a new and potent combination of capabilities the Russian Northern Grouping of Forces has assembled to restore momentum to its counteroffensive in Kursk.

For starters, the Russian 177th Marine Regiment, 810th Naval Infantry Brigade and 11th Air Assault Brigade once again are backed by significant numbers of North Korean troops.

The North Korean 11th Army Corps temporarily withdrew from the front line in Kursk in December or January after losing a third of its 12,000 troops in costly assaults on the Kursk salient late last year. It seems the corps is back with fresh troops.

A Ukrainian MiG-29 bombs a warehouse sheltering Russian vehicles.
Via WarTranslated

Drone surge

More importantly, the Kremlin has pushed one of its best drone groups, the Rubicon Center of Advanced Unmanned Systems, into the Kursk fight—blunting Ukraine’s main advantage: its superior drones. “Rubicon employs advanced drone tactics,” independent analyst Andrew Perpetua explained.

They often target short sections of roads—100 to 300 meters long—and saturate these areas with drones. Attacks are frequently carried out in groups, sometimes striking the front, back, and sides of a vehicle almost simultaneously. This approach has also been used to hit multiple vehicles in a convoy at once, compounding the damage. They also set traps by landing drones on roads and detonating them under passing vehicles, functioning like anti-tank mines—likely using upward-facing shaped charges.

With well-made drones and radio control systems that can apparently rapidly switch frequencies, Rubicon has managed to fight through Ukrainian jamming, which normally has the effect of grounding most Russian drones.

As a result, “Ukrainian logistics in Kursk have suffered severe damage from drone attacks,” Perpetua explained. Rubicon has knocked out hundreds of Ukrainian vehicles—mostly supply trucks, but also precious M-2 Bradley fighting vehicles and MaxxPro armored trucks.

“Numbers are definitely not [on] our side,” wrote Kriegsforscher, a Ukrainian marine corps drone operator who has fought in Kursk.

The Ukrainian air force sortied at least one Mikoyan MiG-29 fighter to bomb a warehouse sheltering Russian armored vehicles supporting the Kursk counteroffensive. Ukrainian troops reportedly defeated an incursion by Russian troops sneaking through an old pipeline into Sudzha.

What the Ukrainian force in Kursk really needs are new radio jammers. “Without significant advancements in jamming technology to counter Rubicon's capabilities, maintaining a hold in Kursk may become unsustainable,” Perpetua warned.

Editorial StandardsForbes Accolades
news.summary: Russian advances threaten the only supply line to Ukrainian forces in Kursk.
news.author: David Axe,Forbes Staff
